# Morning Docket: 03.21.18
## * The President apparently got around? Former Playboy Playmate Karen McDougal has filed suit against American Media, Inc., owner of The National Enquirer, to get out of an agreement that's preventing her from discussing her alleged affair with Donald Trump, which reportedly occurred around the same time as the Stormy Daniels affair. [[CBS News](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/karen-mcdougal-files-lawsuit-to-discuss-alleged-trump-affair/)] * What's going on at Latham & Watkins in the wake its former chairman [Lathaming himself over inappropriate conduct](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/latham-watkins-chair-resigns-over-sexual-messages/) involving "communications of a sexual nature"? According to a source at the firm, "[e]veryone is shocked" and no one has any idea who will replace Bill Voge as chair. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/03/20/latham-watkins-copes-with-leaders-sudden-sex-tinged-ouster/)] * "This is not what the impeachment power is for...." Pennsylvania GOP lawmakers are moving to impeach the Democratic state Supreme Court justices who ruled the state’s congressional map was unconstitutionally gerrymandered. [[Huffington Post](https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/pennsylvania-republicans-move-to-impeach-supreme-court-democrats-for-gerrymandering-ruling_us_5ab16875e4b0decad044dee0)] * Dechert has settled an age and sex discrimination case filed by female staff members. There are no details of the settlement available, but if you recall, the firm countered the ex-staffers' claims by saying that [technological advances had made their jobs redundant](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/biglaw-firm-uses-technology-as-a-defense-in-discrimination-case/). [[Legal Intelligencer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/03/20/dechert-settles-female-staffers-sex-discrimination-case/)] * On Monday, Mississippi Governor Phil Bryant signed the most restrictive abortion bill in the country, banning abortion after 15 weeks of gestation. Less than 24 hours later, Judge Carlton Reeves granted a temporary restraining order in favor of the state's lone abortion clinic. [[Associated Press](https://apnews.com/8b2ef41e34ed469a97ff84c27f9f2649/Judge-temporarily-blocks-Mississippi's-15-week-abortion-ban)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 21, 2018 at 8:37 AMMarch 20, 2018 at 10:56 PM
5

# The Biglaw Firm Accused Of Union-Busting Techniques In Media Negotiations
## Giving Biglaw a bad name.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 13, 2018 at 5:17 PMDecember 13, 2018 at 2:23 PM
9
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/the-biglaw-firm-accused-of-union-busting-techniques-in-media-negotiations/&text=The%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Accused%20Of%20Union-Busting%20Techniques%20In%20Media%20Negotiations)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/the-biglaw-firm-accused-of-union-busting-techniques-in-media-negotiations/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/the-biglaw-firm-accused-of-union-busting-techniques-in-media-negotiations/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
What Biglaw firm represents Slate management in the online publication’s question for unionization? Slate’s legal writer, Mark Joseph Stern, says of management’s stance in the negotiations, “It’s appalling that management has not only taken this position but hired a notorious union-busting law firm to enforce it in the face of opposition from every single person on staff.”

Hint: It’s not the firm’s first brush with right-of-center notoriety.

See the answer on the next page.

# Be Prepared, Because More Biglaw Layoffs Are Coming
## The third quarter could get pretty rough at some firms.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJuly 15, 2020 at 3:15 PMJuly 15, 2020 at 2:04 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/be-prepared-because-more-biglaw-layoffs-are-coming/&text=Be%20Prepared,%20Because%20More%20Biglaw%20Layoffs%20Are%20Coming)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/be-prepared-because-more-biglaw-layoffs-are-coming/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/be-prepared-because-more-biglaw-layoffs-are-coming/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Firms are getting to grips with the idea that the economy will stay down for a while. The next step is structural change. Clients are thinking about how to lower legal costs and still meet their needs, and as we get into the fall, two things will happen: firms don’t want to be seen doing layoffs until they have to, but they’re also realizing the economy will be down for a while, maybe the next year and a half. This is all coming at the normal timing of annual associate reviews.

I think that layoffs are coming. It’s cruel to let someone go in the middle of a pandemic, and it’s really hard to fire someone over Zoom. Nobody wants the stigma of doing something like that.

— Hugh Simons, a law firm strategist who formerly served as chief operating officer at Ropes & Gray, commenting on the [likelihood of law firm layoffs other serious austerity measures](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/07/14/a-2nd-wave-of-potential-layoffs-looms-over-law-firms-3rd-quarter/) that could take place in the third quarter of 2020. Some firms have already conducted associate and staff layoffs (see [here](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/am-law-200-firm-conducts-associate-layoffs-due-to-covid-19/) and [here](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/am-law-200-firm-lays-off-attorneys-due-to-covid-19/)) as they assess the damage the pandemic has done to their bottom lines.

# The Most Successful Biglaw Firms On Earth, According To ChatGPT (2023)
## It took the chatbot quite a few tries to get this ranking in shape.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 15, 2023 at 11:17 AMFebruary 15, 2023 at 11:15 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/the-most-successful-biglaw-firms-on-earth-according-to-chatgpt-2023/&text=The%20Most%20Successful%20Biglaw%20Firms%20On%20Earth,%20According%20To%20ChatGPT%20(2023))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/the-most-successful-biglaw-firms-on-earth-according-to-chatgpt-2023/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/the-most-successful-biglaw-firms-on-earth-according-to-chatgpt-2023/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The vast majority of law firm rankings depend on revenue, profits, and prestige, and here at Above the Law, we’ve covered just about every one of them. Now comes a new global Biglaw ranking that relies on revenue, number of clients, reputation, awards, and recognition by industry peers — and this time, it was conducted not by a leading legal industry publication, but by a robot.

It seems that ChatGPT, the chatbot that’s taken the legal profession by storm, has stepped into the law firm rankings game. [Law.com International](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/02/13/hello-chatgpt-which-is-the-best-law-firm-in-the-world-405-117321/) recently asked the AI tool to name the most successful law firms in the world. Here are the seven Biglaw firms it came up with on its first try:

- Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom: A leading global law firm known for its expertise in complex corporate transactions and securities law.
- Sullivan & Cromwell: A prestigious New York-based law firm with a strong reputation in mergers and acquisitions, investment banking, and international finance.
- Cravath, Swaine & Moore: Another highly regarded New York-based law firm known for its expertise in corporate and securities law.
- Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton: A global law firm with a strong presence in Europe and Asia, known for its expertise in corporate law, finance, and international arbitration.
- Simpson Thacher & Bartlett: A prominent law firm based in New York, known for its work in M&A, private equity, and capital markets.
- Latham & Watkins: A leading global law firm with a strong presence in the United States, Europe, Asia, and the Middle East, known for its expertise in corporate law, finance, and litigation.
- White & Case: An international law firm with a strong presence in Europe, the Middle East, Africa, and Asia, known for its expertise in cross-border transactions, project finance, and capital markets.
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Pardon me, ChatGPT, but it looks like you’ve forgotten quite a few firms. Where’s Kirkland? What about Wachtell? Why aren’t any Magic Circle firms being mentioned? Come on, shouldn’t Davis Polk be here? Maybe Paul Weiss, too? It took our new robot overlord three more tries to come up with answers about the firms that were left out of its first round of ranking Biglaw elites.

“I apologize for leaving out some important firms in my previous answer,” ChatGPT said, going on to offer some basic facts about the missing firms, and later referring to them as being “among the most successful and prestigious law firms in the world.”

So, why did ChatGPT name the firms it did, and why were so many missing? This was the bot’s response, per Law.com International:

The names of the law firms I mentioned are some of the most well-known and highly regarded law firms in the world. These firms have a long history of providing high-quality legal services and have established a reputation for excellence in their respective fields.

In my response, I aimed to provide a comprehensive list of some of the top law firms globally, and the firms I named are widely regarded as some of the best in the industry. I did not include all law firms as the list would have been too exhaustive, but these firms are a good representation of the top law firms in the world.

And there you have it, just some of the most successful Biglaw firms in the world, according to ChatGPT. Just like its [questionable thoughts](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/chatgpt-crowns-clarence-thomas-as-champion-of-gay-rights-in-feedback-loop-of-stupid/) on prominent Supreme Court cases, the AI bot’s grasp of the best firms on Earth seems a little off. But, at least it’s learning some lawyerly CYA moves, like claiming that a full list of the best Biglaw firms would have been “too exhaustive” to name.

[Hello ChatGPT, Which is the Best Law Firm in the World?](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/02/13/hello-chatgpt-which-is-the-best-law-firm-in-the-world-405-117321/) [Law.com International via American Lawyer]

# Morning Docket: 08.01.16
## * If you thought you were going to be making $180K after graduation, then you better lower your expectations by quite a bit. Be prepared to make less than $65K! The National Association for Law Placement has released its annual edition of the bi-modal salary distribution for recent law school graduates, and the wide chasm between peaks on the bell curve looks more unhealthy than ever. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/banking-on-a-180k-entry-salary-check-this-out/)] * In the wake of the Democratic National Convention, everyone wants to know the names on Hillary Clinton's Supreme Court shortlist. It might surprise you that insiders say President Obama's nominee, Merrick Garland, is at the top of Clinton's list of eleven potential candidates. We'll have more information on this later today. [[The Hill](http://thehill.com/regulation/court-battles/289643-clintons-court-shortlist-emerges)] * "What we're seeing is a sort of shift around social norms. Kennedy is the best Geiger counter. He's a very good instrument for measuring that." SCOTUS seems to be cutting back on its defense of religious freedom in favor of supporting government regulators, and the high court's swinger has led the way in the wake of Scalia's passing. [[USA Today](http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2016/07/30/supreme-court-religious-liberty-freedom-abortion-contraception/86819172/)] * Federal prosecutors from the Manhattan U.S. Attorney's Office and the DOJ are now investigating whether Mossack Fonseca, the infamous firm behind the Panama Papers, knowingly assisted its clients in laundering money and/or evading taxes. A firm spokesperson has denied all accusations of criminal wrongdoing. [[Wall Street Journal](http://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-prosecutors-probe-panama-papers-law-firms-employees-1469737691)] * "You can sentence me to whatever you want, I guess. This sentence, I won't outlive it." Convicted murderer Drew Peterson was sentenced to an additional 40 years in prison in a murder-for-hire plot to kill prosecutor James Glasgow. In 2047, Peterson will be 93 years old, and he'll be up for parole for the murder of his third wife. [[Chicago Tribune](http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-drew-peterson-sentencing-met-20160729-story.html)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 1, 2016 at 8:59 AMJuly 31, 2016 at 8:47 PM

# Morning Docket: 04.04.17
## Even conservatives are concerned about the damage that invoking the nuclear option for Judge Gorsuch's SCOTUS nomination will do. * "This is going to haunt the Senate, it’s going to change the judiciary, and it’s so unnecessary." Senate Democrats have secured the votes to filibuster Judge Neil Gorsuch's Supreme Court nomination, all but ensuring that Senate Republicans will invoke the nuclear option, and even conservatives are concerned about the damage it will do. [[New York Times](https://nytimes.com/2017/04/03/us/politics/senate-democrats-appear-poised-to-filibuster-gorsuch-nomination.html)] * It turns out that the Wallace Global Fund tried hire another Biglaw firm to replace Morgan Lewis & Bockius prior to [kicking the firm to the curb](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/should-lawyers-and-law-firms-pay-a-price-for-normalizing-the-trump-regime/) over its representation of President Donald Trump. Apparently Arnold & Porter "would have been perfect," but that firm represents Trump too, so it was a "deal killer." [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/fund-client-explains-decision-to-fire-morgan-lewis/)] * "It’s like a marriage but infinitely complex. In the beginning, it was appealing, but as you went along you see the synergies are not there." Following a [short romance](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/a-biglaw-holiday-romance-d-c-powerhouse-cuddles-up-to-prominent-new-york-firm/), it looks like Crowell & Moring and Herrick Feinstein are breaking off their engagement before wasting their time getting married and going through a messy divorce. [[New York Post](http://nyp.st/2nTQ1j4)] * You give love legal ethics a bad name: Remember Tara Lenich, the ADA who was accused of forging judges' signatures to wiretap a love interest and a coworker in a ["love triangle gone wrong"](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/prosecutor-in-hot-water-for-using-a-wiretap-to-spy-on-a-love-interest/)? She pleaded guilty to two charges of illegal wiretapping, and could face up to 10 years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000. [[Brooklyn Daily Eagle](http://www.brooklyneagle.com/articles/2017/4/3/former-brooklyn-ada-pleads-guilty-forging-judges-signatures-wiretapping)] * If you're a prospective law student with a learning disability or attention disorder, you may be worried about keeping up with the rigors of legal study. Don't let it get you down. Request an accommodation, but make sure you do so before it's too late or you may screw yourself out of getting the help you need. [[Law Admissions Lowdown / U.S. News](https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/law-admissions-lowdown/articles/2017-04-03/learn-how-to-navigate-learning-disabilities-in-law-school)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 4, 2017 at 8:56 AMApril 4, 2017 at 10:06 AM
3

Justice Gorsuch? (Photo by Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)

* “This is going to haunt the Senate, it’s going to change the judiciary, and it’s so unnecessary.” Senate Democrats have secured the votes to filibuster Judge Neil Gorsuch’s Supreme Court nomination, all but ensuring that Senate Republicans will invoke the nuclear option, and even conservatives are concerned about the damage it will do. [[New York Times](https://nytimes.com/2017/04/03/us/politics/senate-democrats-appear-poised-to-filibuster-gorsuch-nomination.html)]

* It turns out that the Wallace Global Fund tried hire another Biglaw firm to replace Morgan Lewis & Bockius prior to [kicking the firm to the curb](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/should-lawyers-and-law-firms-pay-a-price-for-normalizing-the-trump-regime/) over its representation of President Donald Trump. Apparently Arnold & Porter “would have been perfect,” but that firm represents Trump too, so it was a “deal killer.” [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/fund-client-explains-decision-to-fire-morgan-lewis/)]

### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  

* “It’s like a marriage but infinitely complex. In the beginning, it was appealing, but as you went along you see the synergies are not there.” Following a [short romance](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/a-biglaw-holiday-romance-d-c-powerhouse-cuddles-up-to-prominent-new-york-firm/), it looks like Crowell & Moring and Herrick Feinstein are breaking off their engagement before wasting their time getting married and going through a messy divorce. [[New York Post](http://nyp.st/2nTQ1j4)]

* You give love legal ethics a bad name: Remember Tara Lenich, the ADA who was accused of forging judges’ signatures to wiretap a love interest and a coworker in a [“love triangle gone wrong”](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/prosecutor-in-hot-water-for-using-a-wiretap-to-spy-on-a-love-interest/)? She pleaded guilty to two charges of illegal wiretapping, and could face up to 10 years in prison and a fine of up to $250,000. [[Brooklyn Daily Eagle](http://www.brooklyneagle.com/articles/2017/4/3/former-brooklyn-ada-pleads-guilty-forging-judges-signatures-wiretapping)]

* If you’re a prospective law student with a learning disability or attention disorder, you may be worried about keeping up with the rigors of legal study. Don’t let it get you down. Request an accommodation, but make sure you do so before it’s too late or you may screw yourself out of getting the help you need. [[Law Admissions Lowdown / U.S. News](https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/law-admissions-lowdown/articles/2017-04-03/learn-how-to-navigate-learning-disabilities-in-law-school)]
